frameDefinitions: An Evader moves under its own power to thereby avoid Capture  or contact with a Pursuer, also generally moving under its own power.
The Hearer receives a Message or communication on a particular Topic.
A Reader visually examines a Text, typically in a linear order, to understand its content.
This frame contains perception words whose perceivers intentionally direct their attention to some entity or phenomenon in order to have a perceptual experience.
A physical entity, construed as a point-Sound_source, emits a Sound.
In this class of perception words, a Phenomenon, typically expressed as External Argument, and its perceptual characteristics are given some description.
frameExamples: Teenage fans first <t>heard</t> about the tragedy on a popular radio show.
There's a hamburger bar open, and it <t>smells</t> real good.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Evader</fen> moves under its own power to <fen>Capture</fen> or contact with the <fen>Pursuer</fen>. Normally the <fen>Evader</fen> frame element is expressed as an external argument.
The <fen>Pursuer</fen> is going after the <fen>Evader</fen> unless they act.
An actual or hypothetical  event in which the <fen>Pursuer</fen> takes physical control of the <fen>Evader</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> at which the Evading occurs.
This role is the person who receives a Message. It is expressed as an Exteranal Argument in this frame:
The Message is the content that is communicated from one person to another. It is normally expressed as an NP Object or a finite clause Complement:
Topic is the subject matter about which the Message is communicated. It is normally expressed as a PP-complement headed by <ment>about</ment>, with or without a quantificational noun:
The <fen>Time</fen> the <fen>Hearer</fen> receives the <fen>Message</fen>.
The one who examines a <fen>Text</fen> to understand it.
The entity that contains linguistic symbols.
The idea that an implicit <fen>Text</fen> or texts focuses on.
When the reading event takes place.
Where the reading event takes place.
The <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> performs some action in order to have a perceptual experience. It is expressed as an External Argument:

<fen>Phenomenon</fen> indicates the entity or phenomenon to which the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> directs his or her attention in order to have a perceptual experience. Typically, it is expressed as an Object with verbs.
<fen>Body_part</fen> identifies the part of the body used as a sensory organ of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen>, typically expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.

<fen>Direction</fen> is used for all path-like expressions that describe how the perceiver's attention is directed during the act of perception, with the exception of those indicating the location of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> (which would be marked <fen>Location_of_perceiver</fen>)
When the activity of attempting to perceive occurs.
The general location within which the act of perception takes place.

The frame element <fen>Sound_source</fen> is assigned to a constituent referring to a physical entity which emits a sound. Such an entity must have an appropriately complex internal structure such that it can create a sound. For example, a machine or some other thing with moving parts can create sound by itself.

The frame element <fen>Sound</fen> is incorporated in the meaning of the verbs of this frame. Otherwise, this role is assigned to NPs which actually refer to a sound in the presence of the target. This typically occurs when the target is a verb used as a modifier in its <ment>-ing</ment> form, e.g.:
An event in which one or more <fen>Sound_source</fen>s participate and which is accompanied by <fen>Sound</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Noisy_event</fen> occurs.

The location of the <fen>Sound_source</fen>. This role differs from <fen>Location_of_source</fen> only in terms of point of view; the latter role implies a point of view that is not on the <fen>Sound_source</fen>.
The <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is typically the External Argument of the verbs in this frame.
<fen>Characterization</fen> is the subjective description (of the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> ) of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
<fen>Appraisal</fen> is the positive or negative judgement given to the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.

<fen>Inference</fen> expresses some property of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> that is not a direct  feature of the particular sensory modality (if any), but rather is based on perception within that modality.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The mouse</fex> eluded the cats for only a few minutes.
The mouse eluded <fex>the cats</fex> for only a few minutes.
Rýmirez-Sýnchez , tried in absentia , had evaded <fex>capture</fex> since the murders in Paris on June 27 , 1975
Smithers got away <fex>at the stroke of midnight</fex>.
<fex>The students</fex> heard from Pat that class was canceled.
The students heard <fex>the news</fex>.
The students heard <fex>about class</fex>.
I heard <fex>in June</fex> that Pablo left, how sad!
I love reading <fex>about history</fex> .
Charlie often reads the newspaper <fex>at night</fex>.
Surprisingly, few of the students read much at all <fex>in the designated reading rooms</fex>.
<fex>The waiter</fex> smelled the milk to see if it was fresh.
The waiter smelled <fex>the milk</fex> to see if it was fresh.
You should feel the water <fex>with your toes</fex> before jumping in.
The detective looked <fex>across the street</fex> at the suspect.
<fex>The wind</fex> howled.
The branches made a rattling <fex>sound</fex>.
<fex>The conversations</fex> droned on
It's going to beep again <fex>in two minutes</fex>.
A bat squeaked <fex>over our heads</fex>.
<fex>The soup</fex> tasted very salty.
Kim's new furniture looks <fex>sort of bluish</fex>.
Kim's hair feels <fex>nice</fex>.
Pat sounds <fex>devastated</fex> by the bad news.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: - A Man on the Moon: The Voyages of the Apollo Astronauts
the comfort of your home:- Apollo 13
